steps.title: Decide if you want to plant the tree indoors or outdoors.
steps.content: Decide if you want to plant the tree indoors or outdoors. Cinnamon trees will do well in either location, as long as they receive around full sun. If the temperatures in your area fall below 68 °F (20 °C), then it might be best to plant the cinnamon indoors. [1] X Research source You don't have to keep a potted cinnamon indoors year-round. You can keep it outside and bring it in only when the temperatures drop below 68 °F (20 °C).

steps.title: Choose a location that receives 12 hours of sunlight every day.
steps.content: Choose a location that receives 12 hours of sunlight every day. Full sun is a must for cinnamon, so some place that receives around 12 hours of full sunlight each day would be ideal. [2] X Research source If this is an indoor tree, a south-facing window would be ideal because the sunlight would be stronger. If you are keeping the tree indoors and live in the southern hemisphere, a north-facing window would be better.

steps.title: Buy some well-draining soil from a nursery.
steps.content: Buy some well-draining soil from a nursery. Do not use soil from the garden, as it may contain harmful bacteria that may contaminate your tree. If the soil isn't labeled as "well-draining," ensure that it contains soil, sand, and perlite. This particular combination will allow the soil to drain well. [3] X Research source For an outdoor tree, you need enough soil to fill a 4 ft (1.2 m) square area. For an indoor tree, you need enough to fill a 24 by 20 in (61 by 51 cm) pot.

steps.title: Ensure that the soil's pH is between 4.5 and 5.5.
steps.content: Ensure that the soil's pH is between 4.5 and 5.5. Cinnamon loves acidic soil, so this pH range is a must. Purchase a pH testing kit from a nursery, then use it to test the soil's pH [4] X Research source If the pH is too high, cover the soil with 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) of sphagnum peat, then work the peat into the first 8 to 12 inches (20 to 30 cm) of soil. It is unlikely that the pH will be lower than 4.5, but if it is, mix some limestone into the soil.

steps.title: Buy a cinnamon tree from a nursery or harvest the seeds yourself.
steps.content: Buy a cinnamon tree from a nursery or harvest the seeds yourself. Whether you buy a young tree or harvest the seeds is up to you. If you choose to harvest the seeds, wait until the berries turn black first, then split them open. Set them out to dry in the shade for 2 to 3 days, then separate and rinse the seeds. Allow them to dry in the shade once more. [5] X Research source Harvest the seeds from strong, healthy cinnamon trees with smooth, easily-peeling bark and a high oil content. Plan to use the seeds within 7 to 10 days. You may be able to purchase fresh cinnamon seeds online, but you need to plant them as soon as possible.

steps.title: Fill a 4 ft (1.2 m) square area with your soil.
steps.content: Fill a 4 ft (1.2 m) square area with your soil. Use a shovel to dig a plot that's at least 4 by 4 feet (120 by 120 cm) and 12 inches (30 cm) deep. Fill the plot with your acidic, well-draining soil. For an indoor tree, use a glazed, 24 by 20 in (61 by 51 cm) ceramic pot with drainage holes instead. Cover the holes in your pot with window screening before you add the soil. This will prevent the soil from falling out.

steps.title: Dig a 12 in (30 cm) hole for your tree.
steps.content: Dig a 12 in (30 cm) hole for your tree. Use a gardening trowel to create a hole that’s 12 inches (30 cm) deep and 12 inches (30 cm) wide. If you are planting a seed, then use your finger or a stick to make a 1 ⁄ 2 in (1.3 cm) deep hole instead. [6] X Research source You can plant multiple seeds in 1 pot because you'll be thinning them out later. Keep the holes about 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) apart. You can only plant 1 tree per 1 4 ft (1.2 m).

steps.title: Set the tree into the hole, then tamp the soil down.
steps.content: Set the tree into the hole, then tamp the soil down. Remove the tree from the flimsy pot that it came in first, then gently loosen the root ball. Set the tree into the hole, then fill the gaps in with more soil. Gently pat the soil down with your hands. If you are starting with seeds, place 1 seed into each hole, then brush soil over the hole.

steps.title: Water the soil.
steps.content: Water the soil. Use enough water to make the soil damp. If you planted your tree in a pot, then keep watering it until the water starts to come out of the drainage hole(s) at the bottom. After this initial watering, you don't need to water the tree again until the top 2 inches (5.1 cm) are dry. Don’t use tap water since it is often treated with chemicals.

steps.title: Thin the seedlings
steps.content: Thin the seedlings once they emerge. Wait until the seedlings form their first set of true leaves; they will be larger and darker than the other leaves. Next, choose the strongest, healthiest-looking seedling, and pluck out the rest. You can discard the plucked seedlings or transplant them into separate pots. If you started with a young tree, then you don’t need to worry about thinning it out.

steps.title: Wait until the top 2 inches (5.1 cm) are dry before watering the tree.
steps.content: Wait until the top 2 inches (5.1 cm) are dry before watering the tree. Depending on how hot and sunny it is, you may end up watering as seldom as once per week to as often as every single day. Once the tree have matured, after about 3 years, you only need to water it during droughts. This is because the roots have grown deep enough to reach the damp soil. Test the soil's moisture by sticking your finger into it. If the soil feels dry, it's time to water.

steps.title: Apply a time-release fertilizer between late winter and early fall.
steps.content: Apply a time-release fertilizer between late winter and early fall. Choose a 8-3-9 or 10-10-10 time-release fertilizer, and apply it in a 20 in (51 cm) radius around the base of the tree. Drag a gardening fork through the fertilizer to mix it into the soil. Do this once or twice each week, starting in late winter and finishing in the fall. You can also use an organic fertilizer made from rotted manure and plants. [7] X Research source Read the instructions that came with your fertilizer to find out exactly when, how much, and how often you should use it. Each brand will be different. Once the tree matures after 2 to 3 years, you should use twice as much fertilizer.

steps.title: Keep a clear 10 to 12 in (25 to 30 cm) radius around tree.
steps.content: Keep a clear 10 to 12 in (25 to 30 cm) radius around tree. This includes things like mulch, grass, weeds, and other ground coverings. All of these things can harbor pests that can harm your tree. To prevent this, keep a 10 to 12 in (25 to 30 cm) radius around the base of the trunk free of any mulch or vegetation. [8] X Research source Vegetation includes things like grass and weeds. Remove the weeds 3 to 4 times per year for the first 2 years. After that, you only need to remove the weeds 1 or 2 times per year.

steps.title: Treat diseased areas with fungicides or remove them.
steps.content: Treat diseased areas with fungicides or remove them. Removing the diseased area is the safest, surest method. In some cases, such as with blight or gray leaf spot, you may be able to use fungicides. In more extreme cases, such as stripe cankers, you'll have to remove the diseased portion. [9] X Research source Watch out for: blight (gray leaf spot), brown root, pink disease, and stripe canker. Don't toss the diseased bark and stems into the compost bin or you'll contaminate it. You need to destroy them. Disinfect your tools afterwards with rubbing alcohol or a solution of 1 part bleach and 9 parts water.

steps.title: Eliminate pests with herbicides.
steps.content: Eliminate pests with herbicides. Insecticides are not very effective because they don't kill the eggs. If you don't kill the eggs, then they will hatch, and you'll have to deal with the pests all over again. [10] X Research source Common cinnamon pests include: borers, caterpillars, jumping plant louse, leaf miners, and mites. Be sure to peel back the bark and treat the area underneath it. This is where all the eggs tend to be. When in doubt, treat the entire stem.

steps.title: Wait until the tree is 2 years old before you harvest it.
steps.content: Wait until the tree is 2 years old before you harvest it. You do not need to prune the tree since the harvesting process will take care of that. You'll know when the tree is ready for harvesting when the bark turns brown and the leaves grow firm.

steps.title: Cut 4 to 6 stems to the ground between late spring and late summer.
steps.content: Cut 4 to 6 stems to the ground between late spring and late summer. Choose 4 to 6 straight, healthy-looking stems, then use a fine-toothed saw to cut them down until they are 1.5 to 2.5 inches (3.8 to 6.4 cm) long. Make sure the cuts at 30-degree angles, slanting towards the middle/inside of the tree. [11] X Research source It would be even better to do so during the rainy season as the bark will be easier to peel away.

steps.title: Cut the shoots into shorter lengths, then score the bark.
steps.content: Cut the shoots into shorter lengths, then score the bark. Something between 3 and 4 inches (7.6 and 10.2 cm) would be ideal. Use a sharp knife to slice the bark apart lengthwise (from top-to-bottom) on each mini shoot. [12] X Research source If the harvested stem was older, you may have to cut a little into the wood.

steps.title: Peel the bark off of the mini shoots, then set it out to dry.
steps.content: Peel the bark off of the mini shoots, then set it out to dry. Use your fingers or a knife to pry the bark away from the wood. Once you have the bark peeled off, set it out in a shady area for about 4 to 5 days so that it can dry out. [13] X Research source The bark will start to curl up naturally on its own after you peel it. This is your cinnamon stick!

steps.title: Wait 2 years before harvesting the cinnamon again.
steps.content: Wait 2 years before harvesting the cinnamon again. Like many other spices, cinnamon can last a long time. This means that your original batch of harvested cinnamon should last you until the next harvest. You can harvest 4 to 6 stems every 2 years. [14] X Research source If this is an indoor tree, you can cut the stems shorter if they are growing too long. Left to itself, a cinnamon tree can grow up to 8 feet (2.4 m). Don’t harvest the same stems each time.
